article.title: Nicolas Guillou, French ICC judge sanctioned by the US and “debanked”

summary: Nicolas Guillou, a French judge at the International Criminal Court, was sanctioned by the US Treasury on August 20, 2025, for authorizing arrest warrants against Israeli officials accused of war crimes. This move is part of a broader US effort targeting ICC personnel, effectively isolating them from the global financial system and complicating their judicial functions.
keyPoints: Sanctions were imposed under a Trump-era decision on August 20, 2025.
Guillou was targeted for approving ICC arrest warrants against Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant.
A total of six ICC judges and three prosecutors, including Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan, have been sanctioned by the US.
The US sanctions list now includes nearly 15,000 individuals, spanning terrorists, mafia figures, authoritarian leaders, and ICC officials.
Sanctions have significant operational impacts, including 'debanking' and restricted access to international banking for sanctioned ICC members.
Guillou has urged European authorities to establish countermeasures to mitigate the effects of US restrictions on ICC work.

rewrite.title: US Sanctions French ICC Judge Over Israel Warrants
rewrite.body:
On August 20, 2025, the US Treasury Department sanctioned Nicolas Guillou, a French judge at the International Criminal Court (ICC), citing his role in authorizing arrest warrants against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant. Both Israeli officials face allegations of war crimes related to the Gaza Strip conflict. This sanction is part of a broader US campaign targeting ICC personnel, including six judges and three prosecutors such as Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan.

The sanctions, originally designed to combat terrorism, human rights abuses, and drug trafficking, have expanded to include nearly 15,000 individuals worldwide. The inclusion of ICC judges signals an unprecedented politicization of international judicial processes, effectively blacklisting these officials from much of the global banking system. Guillou described the impact as severe, highlighting difficulties in conducting daily work and financial transactions due to 'debanking.'

These measures raise concerns about the independence of international justice and the ability of ICC officials to operate without external interference. Guillou has called on European authorities to implement protective mechanisms to shield ICC members from the extraterritorial reach of US sanctions. The situation underscores growing tensions between US foreign policy priorities and multilateral judicial institutions, with potential long-term implications for international law enforcement and cooperation.
